mods:mods.mods:abstract: Until recently, the British were in summer quarters on Port Royal Island. There are creditable reports that many of them have gone to Georgia, leaving one battalion, three light companies and 100 Hessians behind: a total of 500 men. Lincoln hopes that "our little army", composed of 900 men, might be able to beat them, protect the area, and check the Indians. Colonel Parker and Major Jameson are already at Augusta. General Scott is on the march with about 800 men. General Caswell informs Governor Rutledge that not more than 300 Continentals may be expected from North Carolina, where there are now 2000 men in the militia. It will be some time before they arrive, perhaps too late to attack the enemy before its reinforcements arrive. Aid from Virginia and North Carolina fell so far short of what was expected that Lincoln asked them to provide him with not less than 4000 men for the fall campaign. Affairs in the West Indies and in Europe may make it necessary for the British to drawn away part of their troops, leaving an insufficient number. From a vessel just arrived from Havana, Lincoln learned that Spain declared war against Britain. The report of a Spanish ship's crew taken by the British off North Carolina, confirms this. The British are concentrating around Ebenezer, Georgia. Colonel Twiggs and Major Jameson won a small skirmish against them. Autograph letter signed
